name: In Celestial Company
description: Join us for a guided walk of our exhibition, In Celestial Company, led by Vineet Kajrolkar. Shift your focus from the deities and move it to their grand procession of divine helpers, wondrous animals and mythic beings and their fascinating stories.

name: Listening to Images
description:
Join this two-day workshop of creative inquiry and narrative experimentation where you engage with MAP’s latest exhibition, Beneath the Turning Sky. In the workshop, you will make your own short video works, responding to the exhibition through close looking, interpretation and poetic translation. Led by writer and sound researcher Mishika Goel, the workshop offers the space to reflect on how art can be re-encountered, re-imagined, and articulated through new narrative forms.

Drawing from her experiences in France and her creative process behind Prochaine Station: Aristide Briand, Mishika reflects on narrative as both method and medium. The workshop, situated at the intersection of language, moving image, and curatorial encounter, explores how artworks generate meaning beyond the visual- prompting stories, gestures, and varied forms of response..

This workshop is part of the ongoing series, Responding to Art through the Arts. Facilitated by arts practitioners, it aims to activate MAP’s galleries through a series of workshops that hold space for young people’s responses to artwork on display. 

It is conducted as part of our engagements for the MAP Youth Collective - a community for young people (18-25 year olds) to engage with the arts and culture sector. The collective is for, of and by young people — to explore our shared identities and interests through art.

Workshop requirements: Open to all skill levels, any phone camera/professional camera can be used.

name: Visual Vernacular & Poetry
description:
Image Courtesy: SAF, Goa 
Join us for a Visual Vernacular (VV) performance by Deaf performer Benin, followed by an ISL poetry session by Hardeep Singh from the MAP team.

Visual Vernacular (VV) is a dynamic form of visual storytelling used in deaf culture. It involves expressive body movements and facial expressions to convey complex narratives and emotions, emphasising dramatic and artistic elements. Unlike traditional sign language, which focuses on factual communication, VV creates vivid, engaging, and multi-dimensional stories. 

ISL Poetry is a visual form of expression that uses handshapes, movement, facial expressions, and space instead of spoken words. Meaning is created through rhythm, repetition, and emotion in the body. Rather than being translated from spoken language, ISL poetry is composed in the language itself, celebrating Deaf culture and the expressive power of Indian Sign Language.

This performance is held in conjunction with our exhibition, mild tooth of milk, currently on display at the Dutch Warehouse in Fort Kochi.

This series of programs is hosted in collaboration with the Kerala Museum.

name: Say it Like You Meme It
description:
Dancing elephants and egg-women? Textile labels weren’t always serious.

Explore the playful branding of 19th and 20th-century textile trade in our exhibition Ticket Tika Chaap. Join us for a meme-making session where we will provide you with materials and historical context, that you can turn into your own creative meme masterpiece!

name: Make Your Own Celestial Companion
description:
Textile Label Depicting Performers in animal Masks, Unknown, Late 19th–early 20th century, Chromolithograph, POP.08434
Design your own mythical creature! Would it be part meerkat, part deer? Would it have wings or claws? In this hands-on workshop, you'll create your very own celestial companion inspired by the divine beings in our current exhibition, In Celestial Company.

The session begins with a walkthrough of the exhibition, where you'll meet Garuda, Mooshika, and other legendary creatures, before designing and crafting your own unique mythical friend.

name: Hidden in Plain Sight: Clay Sculpture in South Asia
description:
Image Credits: Alexander Burnes, Bamiyan Buddhas, print 1834
Air-dried clay stands among South Asia’s oldest and most widely used mediums for sculpture, along with stone, metal, wood, and fired clay. Typically finished in vivid colour, the medium has been largely overlooked in studies of the region’s arts, often misidentified as stucco and terracotta, or sidelined as too breakable and exuberantly coloured to be “art”’.

This talk brings together some of the most prominent practices across the subcontinent to consider why painted, air-dried clay has been so valued as a medium for figural sculpture, and what its sidelining reveals about the study of art and visual culture.

name: Learn ISL - Kochi Edition
description:
Image Courtesy: Ali Monis Naqvi
Join us for a deaf-led Indian Sign Language workshop for both hearing and deaf audiences–this session will introduce you to basic signs for beginner-level communication, and in relation to the artworks that will surround you at the Dutch Warehouse. 

Hardeep Singh from the MAP team will lead this introductory workshop, introducing signs inspired by afra eisma’s work and rooted in emotional worlds. Through sign language, the workshop explores how we can foster safety and connection when gathering for difficult conversations—finding ways to express without voice, using hands, facial expression, and body movement.

This workshop is held in conjunction with our exhibition, mild tooth of milk, currently on display at the Dutch Warehouse in Fort Kochi.

This series of programs is hosted in collaboration with the Kerala Museum.

name: mild tooth of milk (ISL)
description:
Image Courtesy: Ali Monis Naqvi
Join us for a special Indian Sign Language interpreted, Deaf-led guided walk of mild tooth of milk.

Led by Hardeep Singh and Abiraami PS from the MAP team, this session centres on Deaf perspectives, with Indian Sign Language (ISL) as the primary language of engagement, offering a visual-first, inclusive approach to experiencing the exhibition.

The walkthrough invites us to slow down and experience touch, vulnerability, and connection. Through soft carpets, ceramics, and textiles, eisma creates a space that is both informal and charged with energy, encouraging us to play, gather, and heal.

This walkthrough is held in conjunction with our exhibition, mild tooth of milk, currently on display at the Dutch Warehouse in Fort Kochi. 

This series of programs is hosted in collaboration with the Kerala Museum.

name: The Great Tikat Hunt
description:
It’s game time at Ticket Tika Chaap! Come and discover the art of Indo-British textile trademarks through riddles. This exhibition explores textile labels, known as tikats (tickets), tikas or chaaps, and their art-historical and commercial significance, as perhaps the earliest forms of branding and advertisement, in the 19th and 20th century global colonial market.

Intricately designed, these labels carry nuanced stories within them. This is your chance to decode its narrative—the more clues you find, the closer you get to victory.

name: The Archer in the Celestial Court
description:
Bharatanatyam is often called the dance of the cosmic god Nataraja in common parlance, but a deeper look into history of the making of Bharatanatyam shows this narrative was engineered to erase the courtly origins of the dance form.

Nrithya Pillai's dance is about centering these erased hereditary histories—something she is a part of on account of her identity as being from these families whose performance was criminalised. The most common feature of “hereditary dance” is that the songs are themed around love, and if there is one mythological figure who occupied a significant place in Bharatanatyam repertoire it was the God of Desire—Manmatha, Maaran, Kama, Madhana.

This performance will showcase pieces from the hereditary repertoire that bring focus onto the themes of love, and the poetic beauty of the imagery of how Manmatha is portrayed in these love songs.

name: Recasting the Archive
description:
This immersive, two-day workshop invites participants to intersect their artistic practice with the museum’s collection, using popular culture and horror film ephemera as a starting point. Participants will be introduced to a diverse selection of artworks from the collection and guided by Anusha Vikram and Aadithya S from our collections team, through various creative methodologies for developing new artistic responses, interpretations, and collaborative experiments.

Through discussions, hands-on exercises, and shared reflections, the workshop fosters a highly interactive and participatory environment. Participants will exchange ideas, present their practices, and work in teams to ideate and develop draft outputs across a range of formats.

This workshop is designed for art students and participants who are actively pursuing an artistic practice.

name: Tinctures // According To The Tides
description:
Image Credits: Tinctures
Leading up to the release of their third album According To The Tides, the duo, Nishad Pandey (guitar) and Aman Mahajan (piano), perform in India this February—and we're thrilled to host them at MAP. 

Come experience the magic of their 2021 album, Heads and Tales, live alongside breathtaking improvisations that reveal the beautiful interplay between piano and guitar.

name: Crochet Circle @ mild tooth of milk
description:
Image Courtesy: Ali Monis Naqvi
Crochet Circle is a community-based creative initiative by the Kerala Museum, Kochi.  Aiming to be inclusive and accessible, the programme invites individuals of all ages, abilities, and skill levels to explore the art of crochet. Created as a welcoming space for beginners, hobbyists, students, educators, and anyone seeking mindful group activities, it encourages creativity, learning, and connection through hands-on craft in a supportive environment.

With a focus on mindfulness, experimentation in materials and design, and adaptable teaching approaches, Crochet Circle prioritizes accessibility and participation at every level. The programme fosters a calm, encouraging atmosphere where participants can work at their own pace, express themselves freely, and build a sense of belonging and community through the shared joy of crocheting.

This programme is facilitated by and hosted in collaboration with the Kerala Museum.

Limited spots available!

This workshop is held in conjunction with our exhibition, mild tooth of milk, currently on display at the Dutch Warehouse in Fort Kochi.
